{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3562376,"name":"","username":"LHACK4142","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lhack4142/{size}/196107_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-19T22:20:56.717Z","cooked":"
  • Sometimes, our arm stutters after the bot’s been on for a while. I’ll link the video when it uploads.
  • The issue goes away when we reboot or redeploy
  • We were reflashing and resetting safe parameters on all motor controllers; we’re trying not reflashing to see if that works, and this issue hasn’t shown up yet, but a) I want to be sure, and b) we haven’t tested much with this new code
  • The pivot is being commanded the right setpoints, and it knows its position. It also knows that it’s applying stuttery output.
  • The issue happens whether running a trapezoidalmotionprofile on the rio or pure PID on the sparkmax.

Thanks!

Not flashing the vortices does not work; the issue is still there.
I also forgot to mention that the leader vortex times out while waiting for periodic status 0 when this issue happens.

This sounds like a pretty classic scenario where you run a new Runcommand that drives the motor, but didn’t include the subsystem requirements. Those build up and cause runtime problems.

No, we add the requirement.
Also, reflashing the spark solves the issue.
Will it harm the Spark to just reflash it every minute or two when disabled?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-03-20T00:18:43.185Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":40,"readers_count":39,"score":8.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":496258,"topic_slug":"stuttering-arm-on-2-vortices","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":44763,"username":"tekdemo","name":"Dan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58301,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"coder in the corner"},"post_url":"/t/stuttering-arm-on-2-vortices/496258/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3562496,"name":"Dan","username":"tekdemo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tekdemo/{size}/138330_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-20T00:36:06.942Z","cooked":"

If that’s the case, it might just be that your PID gains are too high. High gains are well known to cause sharp oscillations around the setpoint.

Reflashing/resetting the Flex would (briefly) disable PID output while it handles the new configuration, potentially letting your system settle just out of setpoint, reducing the oscillation temporarily until it slowly encroaches back to it. It’s tough to say without seeing exactly what the behavior is, and what your gains and feed-forwards are. If you can provide your code, that’ll be useful for debugging.
